Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Solid-state sorbents for olefin-paraffin separations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impacts/commercial potential of this I-corps project is derived from significantly lowering the energy required to separate olefin and paraffin gases. This technology could find application in purifying raw olefin products by supplementing or replacing the existing distillation process. Implementation to this application would reduce global energy consumption by approximately 0.3%, equating to economic savings of billions of dollars and environmental savings associated with reduced electricity demand from polluting power sources. This technology could also be used to recover olefins from the waste streams of polymer and specialty chemical production. Implementation here would reduce overall production costs and the burning of the 'waste' olefins, with associated economic and environmental effects and broader impacts such as making high-quality polymer and specialty chemical products more widely available to consumers. This technology could also find application in the separation of specialty di-olefin feedstocks, reducing the production costs of these di-olefins and related products, with flow on benefits of increasing the accessibility of industry and academia to innovating and diversifying the range of specialty polymer products, increasing consumer choice and quality of life.

This I-Corps project is to investigate the commercialization potential of solid-state sorbents for separating olefin and paraffin gases. Previously, a new strategy was developed for designing olefin sorbents. Proof-of-concept investigations of these materials showed that they could achieve olefin/paraffin selectivities of approximately 600:1, making them the most selective known solid-state materials for this separation by an order of magnitude. These materials operate under dry conditions and are resistant to acetylene fouling. These properties overcome key limitations of previously investigated technologies which require water (which greatly increases the complexity of the engineering and prevents integration with the existing distillation process), and are contaminated by acetylene (which poisons sorbents and renders the process ineffective for long-term operations). This I-Corps project will identify the best developmental commercialization pathway for this material, and the customers who will be best served by the resulting olefin/paraffin separation system.

Institution.Name: University of Colorado at Boulder
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
They want you for I-Corps

As a CU Boulder postdoc who just finished the National Science Foundation ‘Innovation Corps’ program, I want to ask you a few questions. How can your research make an impact on the world? Who will use it? What would they do with it? Why will they value it? When will you decide to become an innovative entrepreneur? Can you do it? Should you do it?

If you want to know the answer to any of those questions, then the I-Corps program wants to help you.

Astoundingly, that help includes $50,000 to go through the 7 week I-corps program, in which you are taught by a team of ‘been there, done that’ innovative entrepreneurs who help guide and evaluate the business opportunity around your research and technology.

The general outline of the program will be familiar to most scientists: 1) What did we think? 2) What did we learn? 3) What will we do next?

The scientific method as applied to business. It follows a familiar structure where our hypotheses are preconceptions about how great our technology is, our experiments are talking to people who might use our technology (over 100 people!) to discover what problems they have, and our results are determining whether or not we could solve their problems.

It is incredibly rewarding talking to a person, understanding the challenges they face and realizing you can solve their problem. Worst case scenario? You can’t solve anybody’s problem. Well it’s still pretty gratifying to realize that you just saved yourself 3 years (of your life!) attempting to solve a problem that nobody wanted fixed in the first place. What a way to focus your research going forward!

From our experience there were 3 keys to getting the most out of the program:

1) Find a great business mentor! To find one near CU Boulder, get in contact with the Office of the Vice-Chancellor for Research, Innovation Center of the Rockies, Innosphere, or just go talk to people!

2) Challenge yourself! The I-Corps course is packed with unfamiliar settings and situations.  You’ll see your skills grow! From how to give and take an interview, to your general confidence around extolling the virtues of your technology—and yourself! The program is an excellent crucible for forging character that isn’t developed in a typical research setting.

3) Commit to the process! Quit pretending you know anything about business, eat a slice of humble pie, and commit to working hard with an open-minded attitude to learning. Looking back on your I-corps experience will be like taking a step back from a huge painting, seeing the whole picture will let you realize what you’ve learned. Hindsight is 20/20, so commit to a new experience that you can look back on!

To find out more about the NSF I-Corps program, search for it on the web, attend one of their monthly phone conferences, contact the program director Steven Konsek.

Happy Innovating!

Matthew Cowan, Zoban Singh, and Mark Gorham

 


Last Modified: 03/02/2018
Modified by: Matthew G Cowan
